44.Content: Whilst I'm waiting for my fabric to arrive, I raided my fabric stash. I came across quite a few metres of this Laura Ashley fabric which was initially intended for making curtains. I washed the fabric twice at 90 degrees and tumble dried on a hot setting before cutting out. I have managed to make four tunics and four pairs of trousers as well as four laundry bags. These will be going directly to a friend that I did my nurses' training with as she has had great difficulty in getting hold of any scrubs. Stay safe everyone xxx

50.Content:
Please delete if not allowed
Hi guys,
Sorry to be pessimistic but if you are one of the many who have expressed an interest in testing key workers, I’d be careful about buying scrubs and theatre shoes (with your own money) at this point.
The email sent on Monday from SYMPL Medical states;
“Antibody tests are still being independently validated by Public Health England and we currently have no information when or if a test will become available.
We are unable to proceed until we have Government support for this venture.
It may be that the Government favour other options but at least we will feel that we have tried to help”
I therefore think there is a possibility that it won’t happen and (again, sorry to be pessimistic), should this be the case, you will have wasted your money and will have scrubs and shoes that are desperately needed by others. I, for one will be gutted if this falls through so am keeping my fingers crossed.

55.Content:

84.Content: Slightly off-topic, but there’s a lot of healthcare workers about on this page.. I keep seeing pics of people in our scrubs, but wearing their own shoes. Is this normal in the NHS during COVID-19? Isn’t everyone missing a viral vector? I ask because having lived on a farm through the Foot and Mouth outbreak in cattle in the early 2000s, disinfecting our footwear and car tyres as we moved in and out of the farm was non-negotiable. On the basis of that farm experience, my fam have rubber/plastic soled shoes for outside that get Miltoned when we step out the front, and separate wellies for our back garden. We live in a terrace so have no driveway, and our road is used by dog walkers and lots of people (an amazing number of whom still spit in this day and age). Maybe I’m being OTT. But I’m interested..

268.Content:
Anyone else with knowledge of an AEG 3500 overlocker who can give me some advice so I can get going on scrubs?
I treated myself to one a few years ago, since it arrived it stayed in the box because a) I was terrified of it, and b) life and operations got in the way.
So getting cracking on scrubs bags then scrubs I thought I'd get myself going.
It's out of the box, plugged in, light came on, start up noise made...light went off... overlocker off. I've tried plugging into different sockets with no joy.
There is a safety micro switch on a spring, which *may have switched, but I don't know how to tell.
If anyone can help so I can get going, I'd really appreciate it 💙💙
If all else fails I'll revert to zigzag on the sewing machine!

329.Content:
Welcome! We are a network of voluntary community groups who love to sew, and are making scrubs to order for NHS staff in the United Kingdom who are struggling to get them during this crisis.
To find out more visit our website https://scrubhub.org.uk/
If you'd like to volunteer please visit the directory on our website and contact a local hub. https://scrubhub.org.uk/allhubs/
If you cant see any close to you and have the skills and equipment to set up your own hub please head here https://scrubhub.org.uk/start-your-own/
If you are looking to order scrubs please visit our website directory where you will be able to order scrubs from an established team near you. if you cant see any please post your request and we will try and match you with a hub. https://scrubhub.org.uk/allhubs/
We've been doing this in north east london and its working really well!! 💙

342.Content: Do we have any indication as to when UK factories will begin filling the orders or deliveries from overseas will arrive, and our stop-gap measures will no longer be needed? 346.Content: I’m so pleased to have found you! We’re makers of bespoke soft furnishings and we’d love, love, love to help make scrubs, bags etc....we’ve an army of makers and fabrics that’ll suit bags but not scrubs, too stiff but with your guidance we can definitely help. I don’t see our local Hospital listed, we’re Rye and Hastings, East Sussex. But I’ve read your info and I know a senior manager at the local trust so if I’m right I need to have them contact you via the email initially?? Excited to be of use!! X

348.Content:
This group is an absolutely fantastic idea, and I’m just gutted I’ve only just found out about it. My sister is a nurse at Chesterfield Royal (not sure if we already have an organised connection there), and I know the struggles they’re currently facing, after this week having to purchase three sets of scrubs herself.
I’m wanting to know if there’s any additional way that I can help the cause personally? I own a luggage start-up, based in Nottinghamshire, and come from a family of machinists/cutters. We have a few machines, and will be starting to produce scrubs as soon as possible. Like many others, business is on a pause, and the world seems to have stopped in many ways, and I feel like time could be spent doing something positive.
Where’s everyone sourcing fabrics from? Unfortunately it’s not a type of fabric we use, however, I have numerous relationships with fabric mills in the Far East that I could contact to support and have air freighted over if we could club together for lower costs? I’m sure the mills would also support on the price.
Have people been setting up personal go fund me pages / just giving pages to fund buying materials? I know a lot of people that can’t sew, but would love to contribute I’m sure. Just an idea if this hasn’t been done as I saw there was something set up initially, however, I’m sure with strength in numbers we can reach more people!
I’m also more than happy to amend any patterns if necessary as things develop, or any branding needed to help spread the word further.
Let me know if there’s anything else I can do to help, additionally to making scrubs.
Keep up the great work everyone, and stay safe!

72.Content:
My husband David and his colleagues work in a very busy GP practice in Waltham Abbey. They face the worst of this terrible disease every day, dealing with those who are very unwell with Covid 19, those that are less unwell with it, those that are just very frightened and many concerned or bereft relatives. Many of the stories are deeply distressing and seemingly relentless. They also have to deal with all the other illnesses people are coping with. It is a difficult time.
Part of their work is to look after two care homes. In many ways these are the places worst hit, as confused and terrified elderly patients face the prospect of either going into hospital to die alone and in terrible pain, or stay in the home to face this brutal disease without oxygen and other medicines. It has been a truly tragic few days, with no sign of it relenting. David describes those working inside the homes as beyond heroes, doing a palliative nurses job with little training and minimum wage, as their traumatised colleagues fall ill around them. It’s a sobering thought that some of us out there are facing the hardest job there is in the world at the moment, without either a complaint or a reward.
One of the things we can do to actually help is to assist in kitting the ‘beyond heroes’ in proper PPE gear. The care homes are desperate for better equipment, as their risk is as high as the ITU staff face, yet their kit is designed for dealing with the risk of a community home visit. The homes are called Ashbrook Court and Honey Lane. It’s been a harrowing few weeks.
They urgently require the following:
masks
Gloves
Sanitizers for hands and all kind of disinfectant.
Aprons
Scrubs
Hand washes
Please if you have or work in a business and have access to these things, and would like to help in a real and powerful way, beyond a self-aggrandising gesture or a well-meaning but ultimately unnecessary assist, please let me know and I can have these sent.
Otherwise let’s all take a moment to send our good wishes and prayers to all those working today, whatever they are doing, all united in the battle against this brutal and indiscriminate killer.

75.Content: Just read the instructions for make the sacks. It appears to me that this pattern will take longer to make them then needed. Anyone who's a sewer would understand this. Plus they could be cut on a fold. So that you have only two sides to sew. Stopping any germs being trapped in the bottom seam. Easier for those who are not sewers. Just my thoughts.

93.Content:
I hope you don't mind but I saw this request on another post and your page was mentioned in a comment:
Dear all, the Cardiothoracic Centre at Basildon Hospital have run out of PPE jackets. We are now using donations from local companies.
The ITU is full of covid 19 and the staff are working 12.5 hour shifts with only one break, to minimise PPE usage.
We need Splash Proof jackets or coveralls (the type decorators might wear). Any colour and a mixture of sizes. If you have any, especially companies that may have stock, please donate them. The staff need to remain safe.
Either contact Colne ward 01268 384272. can collect if required.
Thank you 😷💖😷

194.Content:
I have been asked to post this on behalf of my friends daughter. I hope that's ok. I am not able to make all this order myself, as I am busy with other orders at present. Can anyone help with this request? I'm keeping my fingers crossed🤞
Request from the midwives in PRUH in Bromley!
We have run out of scrubs on the maternity unit, which means we are having to wear our own clothes. It's not unusual in our line of work to need to change our full outfit during the course of a shift, as we get covered in all manner of bodily fluids!
I am currently off recovering from covid 19, but have heard of my colleagues even needing to attend theatre in their own clothes as there is literally nothing for them to change into.
I know we are not providing ITU care for critically ill patients with covid 19.
We are however, caring for women in labour with positive results, and also trying to minimise the impact this pandemic is having on their birth experiences. No one is allowed visitors, women are able to have one birth partner with them for labour only, and those providing care must look so scary to them in masks and visors.
So much of our care is unspoken, a reassuring smile is no longer seen.
We normally wear blue or maroon scrubs, but we are not fussy! If anything we feel a bit of colour and fun might help to reassure women that we are not scary and we are very much there for them still.
We are a mixed bag of midwives, so all sizes are needed.
If we concentrate on the birth centre initially, then the laundered scrubs can be focused on labour ward and ITU where the member of staff wearing them are in the highest risk areas.
We have three- four members of the team working each 12.5 hour shift, so as team we would need 55-60 pairs of scrubs to see us through the week. With a fairly even spread between small, medium, large and extra large. We have some very petite midwives so small definitely true to size, otherwise we can all wear much bigger scrubs than our size so if in doubt go large!
We would be so so grateful for any scrubs for the Oasis Birth Centre, PRUH, BR6 8ND.
Many many thanks in advance for all you amazing key workers of the community helping us to keep caring for women and their babies.

255.Content:
"The Bag Ladies"
Well just over a week ago I decided to sign myself up to make 10 sets of scrubs for first year doctors at Sandwell Hospital.
While waiting for my fabric to arrive, I was approached by a paediatric nurse at the same hospital to make some scrub bags. I made a few with some fabric I had in my stash.
Talking about this with Rachel Bury, my sister, I explained that I had exhausted any suitable fabric I had. She suggested asking Mum, who was an experienced seamstress before a nasty accident which injured her shoulder and wrist, if we could raid her sewing room. As well as this Rachel put out a post requesting donations of fabric and clean bed linen. The response was incredible and after driving around Worcester collecting these fantastic donations, Rachel and I met halfway between Worcester and Kidderminster for her to give them to me to bring home to cut out and sew. I managed to put together about 70 🤪
Then I had a call to say my scrubs fabric was ready to be collected 😱 There was no way I could possibly make use of all these kind donations as well as make the scrubs single handed 🤔
This is when all you wonderful volunteers came to my rescue when you answered my cry for help 🙏
Over the past week, together with Jane Rowland, Jan Moir, three friends from my art class, plus several others I have probably forgotten to mention, the 'team' has worked very hard and I am incredibly proud of every single one of you 👏👏👏
I know that a few of you have sent your bags to Worcester hospitals 👍 and we still have a few more to collect in but when Rachel handed me all the completed bags this morning I was overwhelmed 😲
This afternoon, I was absolutely thrilled to be able to hand over for Sandwell Hospital .....
290 bags and 10 sets of scrubs !!!!!!
Well done Bag Ladies 😁😁😁😍😍😍😍👏👏👏👏👏
On behalf of the NHS and myself, I want to say a massive thank you to you all 💙❤
One last thing, I want to extend a special hug and thanks to Rachel Bury, without whom none of this would have been possible. I'm sure you will all agree that she has done an amazing job, coordinating and executing the distribution of materials and collection of completed bags in these difficult days of social distancing 💖
Stay safe Bag Ladies
Love and best wishes
Debbie xxxxx

269.Content: Hi all .. I hope your all ok at this horrid time.. iv been recommended this site as I work for Thames ambulances in canvey .. we do PTS and we are often in A&E close to suspected/ positive covid patients .. we have ambulances for suspected covid patients .. we are low on facetime masks .. we get approx 4 to last a week instead of their 4 hour life span.. we have sore ears , dry mouths, tiredness and headaches from these masks. Other than that we only have rubber gloves and plastic aprons... i believe we have some scrub bags being made .. but if anyone cal help out with face masks we would be more than grateful.. thank you in advance .. stay safe all xx

275.Content: Several doctors have told me - NO NEED FOR POCKETS on trousers. Saves time & fabric, also removes need for side seam. Pockets encourage carrying infected things, and trousers to fall down!
